docs.snippet: DEBRA WINGER and her husband, Arliss Howard, are accustomed to questions about why Ms. Winger left the movie business six years ago. And they have a good answer as to how Mr. Howard, the star and director of Ms. Winger's new comeback film, ''Big B...
docs.lead_paragraph: DEBRA WINGER and her husband, Arliss Howard, are accustomed to questions about why Ms. Winger left the movie business six years ago. And they have a good answer as to how Mr. Howard, the star and director of Ms. Winger's new comeback film, ''Big Bad Love,'' lured his wife back into acting. He promised her a Highland cow.
docs.abstract: Dana Kennedy profiles and interviews actress Debra Winger and husband Arliss Howard, who comment on her return to big screen in film Big Bad Love, starring and directed by Howard; photos (M)

headline.main: Back From a Long Break, But on Her Own Terms

docs.snippet: MARCIA GAY HARDEN won an Oscar for her role as Lee Krasner in POLLOCK (2000). Ed Harris, who directed and stars as the title character, should have. He's painfully on target as Jackson Pollock, Abstract Expressionist, whose fame just aggravates hi...
docs.lead_paragraph: MARCIA GAY HARDEN won an Oscar for her role as Lee Krasner in POLLOCK (2000). Ed Harris, who directed and stars as the title character, should have. He's painfully on target as Jackson Pollock, Abstract Expressionist, whose fame just aggravates his ego, temper and drinking. Krasner, his wife, puts aside her own artistic career to nurture his, but to no avail. He kills himself and a companion in a drunken-driving accident This is a rare film in that it avoids all the cliches about the creative process. It's fascinating, too, to see portrayals of art world notables like Willem de Kooning, Clement Greenberg and Peggy Guggenheim -- Friday at 4 p.m. on Cinemax.
docs.abstract: Capsule reviews of some films on television this week; photos (S)

docs.snippet: In his first report on the troubled Police Department in Wallkill, N.Y., a federal monitor has said that no new complaints have been made against the force, which was accused last year of harassing women and intimidating its critics.     But the m...
docs.lead_paragraph: In his first report on the troubled Police Department in Wallkill, N.Y., a federal monitor has said that no new complaints have been made against the force, which was accused last year of harassing women and intimidating its critics. But the monitor, Dean M. Esserman, remained ''cautiously optimistic'' about improvements in the past seven months, he wrote in his report, which was obtained yesterday by The New York Times.
docs.abstract: Federal monitor Dean M Esserman reports no new complaints have been made against police force in Wallkill, New York, which was accused last year of harassing women and intimidating critics (S)

headline.main: Police Dept. In Wallkill Has Improved, Monitor Says

docs.snippet: This country's sad state of health care for the poor and disenfranchised is a great movie subject. Until that film comes along, we'll have to endure ''John Q.,'' which will leave most audiences in dire need of medical attention, though it would be...
docs.lead_paragraph: This country's sad state of health care for the poor and disenfranchised is a great movie subject. Until that film comes along, we'll have to endure ''John Q.,'' which will leave most audiences in dire need of medical attention, though it would be hard to say if that need will come from the painful collection of plot clichés or Aaron Zigman's assaultive soundtrack. ''John Q.'' is a remarkable document, so ham-fisted that it sabotages its own worthwhile arguments. Denzel Washington, who just received a well-deserved Oscar nomination for his work in ''Training Day,'' finally does the kind of well-meaning everyman-fighting-the-power turn he's been accused of in the past. He's John Quincy Archibald -- yes, the film's title is literal -- a man who's struggling to keep his beleaguered family together. John's factory job has been reduced to part time; he's told he's overqualified for a second job he applies for; his car is repossessed; and then his luck really goes bad.
docs.abstract: Elvis Mitchell reviews movie John Q, directed by Nick Cassavetes; Denzel Washington, Robert Duvall and James Woods star; photo (M)

headline.main: If Arguing Won't Move Insurers, Maybe a Gun Will

docs.snippet: They're Always Happy Campers      What's even harder to find in Manhattan than a space to park your car? The answer's easy: a place to pitch your tent. But even if you weren't planning a family camping trip in February, much less in the city, ther...
docs.lead_paragraph: They're Always Happy Campers What's even harder to find in Manhattan than a space to park your car? The answer's easy: a place to pitch your tent. But even if you weren't planning a family camping trip in February, much less in the city, there's now a very congenial spot to have one: the Theater at Madison Square Garden.
docs.abstract: Laurel Graeber Family Fare column discusses Sesame Street Workshop production Big Bird's Sunny Day Campout at Madison Square Garden, Poppy Seed Players' presentation of children's musical Poppy Seed Purim and New York University production of A A Milne's play Ugly Duckling; drawing (M)

docs.snippet: Across the water is the leviathan called the BBC: a gargantuan producer of all kinds of programming, with five channels and a 24-hour-a-day public. In the water, a blue whale, 100 feet long and with arteries big enough for a man to swim through, c...
docs.lead_paragraph: Across the water is the leviathan called the BBC: a gargantuan producer of all kinds of programming, with five channels and a 24-hour-a-day public. In the water, a blue whale, 100 feet long and with arteries big enough for a man to swim through, cruises azure seas as part of ''The Blue Planet,'' an eight-hour, four-part BBC production about life in the oceans. Last month, the first two parts were shown on the Discovery Channel, and last week, BBC Video released them on cassette and DVD. Writing in The New York Times, Julie Salamon said the series was ''unabashedly, poetically awestruck, yet unsentimental,'' and also called it ''ambitious and beautiful.''
docs.abstract: Home Video column notes release on video of first two segments of BBC television series Blue Planet; photo (M)

headline.main: From the BBC, A Watery World

docs.snippet: When Michael D. Eisner, the longtime chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, takes the stage at the company's annual shareholder meeting in Hartford, Conn., on Tuesday, he is going to have a lot of explaining to do.    Ratings have plummeted 2...
docs.lead_paragraph: When Michael D. Eisner, the longtime chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, takes the stage at the company's annual shareholder meeting in Hartford, Conn., on Tuesday, he is going to have a lot of explaining to do. Ratings have plummeted 21 percent this season among total viewers at the ABC television network, putting ABC in third place. ABC Entertainment has replaced a handful of senior executives in recent years. And Disney's stock price has underperformed not only the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for the last five years but also the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq.
docs.abstract: Walt Disney Co chairman Michael D Eisner, who will address annual shareholder meeting on Feb 19, remains calm despite 21 percent decline in ratings at ABC network, stock falloff and takeover talk; graph; photo (M)

headline.main: Disney's Chief Seems Cool on a Hot Seat

byline.original: By LAURA M. HOLSON with BILL CARTER

docs.snippet: The Energy Department recommended this evening that President Bush designate Yucca Mountain, a volcanic ridge in the desert about 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas, as the main burial spot for radioactive wastes from the nation's nuclear power reac...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Energy Department recommended this evening that President Bush designate Yucca Mountain, a volcanic ridge in the desert about 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas, as the main burial spot for radioactive wastes from the nation's nuclear power reactors and bomb production. The choice is the culmination of an $8 billion, 40-year search, but the project still faces many technological and political hurdles. One is that Nevada has said it will try to block the selection.
docs.abstract: Energy Dept recommends that Pres Bush designate Yucca Mountain as main burial spot for radioactive wastes from nation's nuclear power reactors and bomb production; choice is culmination of $8 billion, 40-year search, but project still faces many technological and political hurdles, including opposition from state of Nevada; site is volcanic ridge in desert 100 miles from Las Vegas; wastes will be dangerously radioactive for hundreds of thousands of years; to win approval to open site, department must persuade safety regulators that leakage will be strictly limited for first 10,000 years; license for project must be approved by Nuclear Regulatory Commission, independent agency (M)

headline.main: Energy Department Recommends Yucca Mountain for Nuclear Waste Burial

docs.snippet: When word went around that there were temporary jobs available for the Olympics, rootless people drifted into Utah from all over the West. Some found work cleaning toilets; others found work selling their plasma for $20.    Broke, they have made t...
docs.lead_paragraph: When word went around that there were temporary jobs available for the Olympics, rootless people drifted into Utah from all over the West. Some found work cleaning toilets; others found work selling their plasma for $20. Broke, they have made their way to skid row, which, in the Western tradition, is situated near the railroad tracks. Yet unlike the tracks in most Western cities, the ones in Salt Lake City run near the heart of downtown. Hundreds of thousands of well-fed tourists are separated from a few thousand ragamuffins by an imaginary fence called Rio Grande Street.
docs.abstract: Many homeless people who came to Salt Lake City, enticed by promise of temporary work related to Olympics, are stranded; extra tight security makes it nearly impossible to jump trains to get out, and panhandling is illegal; city has opened emergency shelter that will close when Games are over; photo (M)

docs.snippet: ''MOOD RIVER,'' the beguiling new design show at the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio, goes to your head like a sip of sparkling burgundy brew. But it won't take away your hunger for meat and potatoes. Subjectivity, atmosphere, the ide...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''MOOD RIVER,'' the beguiling new design show at the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio, goes to your head like a sip of sparkling burgundy brew. But it won't take away your hunger for meat and potatoes. Subjectivity, atmosphere, the idea that ambience can be more powerful than blocks of solid matter: these are among the defining motifs in contemporary architecture and design. There is a need for an exhibition that explores these themes with analytic precision. ''Mood River'' doesn't satisfy that need. Rather, it is an extravagant demonstration in installation techniques, a window display of waves in search of depth. Organized by Jeffrey Kipnis and Annetta Massie, curators on the Wexner's staff, ''Mood River'' fills the entire museum. It is the last show to be presented there before the building shuts down in June, when repairs will begin on its functional deficiencies. Peter Eisenman's design looks more substantial with each visit, however, and the curators have taken full advantage of the building's spatially complex interior.
docs.abstract: Herbert Muschamp review of Mood River, new design show at Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio; photos (M)

headline.main: Design's Mood Swings, From Bliss to Rage
